last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89799533
There are very few simple performance penalties in Rust. There's bounds checking, but that's elided automatically in many cases and can be disabled on a per-case basis.
There are also performance bonuses: Rust has strong aliasing guarantees, which gives optimization opportunities you have to opt into in C using restrict pointers (at the risk of UB). Fortran can also beat C thanks to aliasing.
Rust is easier to optimize than C, partly because the compiler catches many pitfalls and partly because it's just a lot more expressive (like C++).

>>89800377
Benchmarks like that aren't very relevant because they don't reflect how code is written in real life. Is anyone who cares about performance going to implement bubble sort?
Rust code is going to call .sort() or .sort_unstable() on a slice because those are in the standard library. You'll get a timsort-based implementation that's been pored over by experts and is monomorphized for your specific data type. If that's not good enough you can get an off-the-shelf radix sort or parallel sort from a third-party library (and the parallel sort will even be checked for data races by the compiler).
C code might call qsort(), but because it operates with void pointers and function pointers it isn't going to be very fast. Or it might call a handrolled quicksort, which also isn't going to be as fast as a finetuned implementation of a more sophisticated algorithm.
Unless you're building a database engine or something and sorting is so crucial that you can afford to spend twenty hours handrolling a state-of-the-art implementation. In that case it doesn't really matter whether you use C or Rust, enough attention will get them to the same place. But most of the time you're not doing that.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89802912
>Not going to implement sort in most cases
People reimplement malloc in a lot of cases when it comes to game optimizations. I don't doubt they would probably be unsatisfied with the standard library sort and probably would implement their own.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89802985
Are you sure? Memory allocation affects performance throughout the whole program and games programming has allocation patterns that are particularly amenable to optimization. It's actually a very obvious thing to optimize. I don't think anything like that's the case for sorting.
I can imagine going more specialized than a generic sort routine, like maintaining sorted order over time, but Rust's standard library also has tools for that—and in any case it's going to look very different from the ten-line babby's first insertion sort in the blog post.

It made sense by the fact that there were keyboard who could input those characters and of it wasn't because of input inconvenience it would have been a great choice overall

What you will find absurd in APL is the operators arity and precedence, but after a while it's really comfy to get rid of some of the parentheses without resorting to LISP faggottry

Basically
> Unary operators takes the evaluation of its argument
So 
sqrt 4 + double 2.5
is evaluated as 
sqrt(4 + double (2.5))

> Binary operators are infix and takes the immediate left operand and for the right operand it follow the unary operator behaviour (takes the evaluation of everything it's right to it)
So 
2 + 3 times 4 + sqrt 4 + double 2.5
is evaluated as 
2 + times(3, sqrt(4 + double(2.5)))

threads.name: /hsg/ Home Server General Pfsense ed.
threads.com:
No /hsg/ thread currently so I'm making one.

READ THE WIKI! & help by contributing:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server

>NAS Case Guide. Feel free to add to it:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server/Case_guide

/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. Know all about NAS? Learn virtualization. Spun up some VMs? Learn about networking by standing up a OPNsense/pfsense box and configuring some VLANs. There's always more to learn and chances to grow. Think you’re god-tier already? Setup OpenStack and report back.

>What software should I run?
Install Gentoo. Or whatever flavor of *nix is best for the job or most comfy for you. Jellyfin to replace Netflix, nextcloud to replace Googlel, ampache to replace spotify, the list goes on and on. Look at the awesome self-hosted list and ask.

>Why should I have a home server?
Learn something new. De-botnet your life. Serving applications to yourself, your family, and your frens feels good. Put your /g/ skills to good use for yourself and those close to you. Store their data with proper availability redundancy and backups and serve it back to them with a /comfy/ easy to use interface.
